section.title: Purpose
section.para: The purpose of this handbook is to facilitate deployment of &PRODNAME;'s versioning component. This handbook is not a tutorial. It provides basic information that will help you understand and deploy this &PRODNAME; component, but you must adapt this information to suit your own configuration.

Versioning enables ReST services to roll out updates and changes without causing end-client breakage. A new version of the service API can be released, but clients who are not ready to use the new version can specify a preference for the old version. Clients can also request a catalog of available versions; each version in the catalog is marked with a status, such as CURRENT or DEPRECATED, which the client can use for guidance in deciding which version to use.
This handbook is focused on one &PRODNAME; component. Other &PRODNAME; components are documented in companion handbooks.

chapter.title: Message Enhancement and Routing
chapter.para: The &PRODNAME; versioning component's purpose is to annotate incoming requests with their intended destination and to describe the available versions to the user.
The versioning component enhances the incoming request with an HTTP header named X-PP-Service-Origin. This header can be used by components further down the stack to perform routing.
The versioning component does not route requests, nor is it responsible for routing.

chapter.title: Configuration
chapter.para: These examples of the system model and the versioning configuration are designed to demonstrate all available and configurable options.
Key elements of the preceding example are labeled with callouts and explained below:

callout.para: The configuration's service root describes the base URL of the origin service without any versioning information in the URI variant. This value is used to identify requests against the origin service's resource root as well as construct valid, versioned URIs for the origin service.
Version mappings describe the available versions to the requester.
A version mapping must include id, pp-host-id, context-path, status, and media-types.

id: The ID is responsible for two things. First, a service version's ID must uniquely identify the version mapping within the configuration: no two service versions may share the same ID. In addition, the ID must be the resource variant that follows the service root which identifies this version. For example, in http://service.api.vendor.com/root/[v1.0/]path/to/resource, the version variant is within square brackets.
pp-host-id: The power proxy host ID is used to identify which power proxy host will answer to versioned requests that match this version mapping. The power proxy host is defined in the system model.

context-path: The context path attribute is used to indicate that the external mapping for this version, for example the id attribute, is not the internal mapping. The versioning component will then use this path to route the request to its intended destination.

status: A version mapping's status can be either of four strings:
DEPRECATED
ALPHA
BETA
CURRENT
This status may be interpreted by the requester without restriction.

media-types: A version mapping must describe the types of content it can understand and return. These media types must include as human-readable attributes both their base type and the complex type.
The base type is a MIME type without versioning or vendor information.
The complex type is a MIME type with versioning and/or vendor information.
RFC 2046 at http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2046/ describes MIME types.
Atom links are used to richly describe any links that are identified in any returned service version. RFC 4287 at http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4287/ defines the Atom syndication format.

chapter.title: Handling Requests
chapter.para:
Versioning in &PRODNAME; operates on requests in two ways:
introspection of the HTTP Accept header
introspection of the URI variant

note.para: When both the Accept header and the URI variant are specified, introspection of the URI variant always takes precedence.

section.title: Complex Request MIME Types
section.para: The versioning component supports two methods of requesting a service version in the HTTP request.

section.title: Request URI Variants
section.para: In addition to MIME-type introspection, the versioning component supports version tagging via the requested URI variant.

chapter.title: Describing Versions
chapter.para: The versioning component may, upon request, describe all of the available service versions or one particular version.

figure.title: Service Versions Catalog as Response to Versioning Request

section.title: Describing All Versions
section.para: A requester may request that the versioning component describe all available service versions. This is done by requesting the service root without any versioning information in the request.

section.title: Describing a Single Version
section.para:
A requester may request that the versioning component describe a single service version by requesting the service root with versioning information on the request. The service version's root may be requested in two ways:
via URI variant
via complex MIME type

chapter.title: Handling Errors
chapter.para: If a requester makes a request that cannot be mapped to a valid service version, the versioning component will return a 300 (Multiple Choices) as well as a full service version catalog that the requester can then use to make the correct request. The resulting Atom links within the service version catalog will retain the incorrectly-requested resource in an attempt to correctly link the requester to valid, versioned representations.
